Coriolis effect  is an issue in aviation too.... most aircraft do not use compass but a DI (direction Indicator) or in  the US called a HI (heading indicator) that is based on a gyroscope set in the yaw plane, this is because of the effects of banking, accelerating etc on a compass... however over a period of flight the gyroscope starts to drift because of Coriolis effect (and imperfections in the instrument)... therefore pilots need to re-align their DI/HI every so often to correct for it - this is done by setting to the magnetic compass when in a stable, level flight position. (see, tell my flying instructor I was paying attention in class!!) - I love this science.... great video!!!

That's an enormous pool of water for such a tiny drain hole. increase the diameter of that hole to 30 centimeters and you will see a significant difference in the centrifugal power yield of the vortex. your pool example is like having a drain hole the size of your pinky finger on a toilet, and neither jets, design or Coriolis will cause a significant vortex when flushed. A typical toilet drain hole is 1/5 to 1/7 the size of the actual water volume held in the bowl. Makes a big difference to the extent that it may actually debunk some part of your conclusion in this video.

It is true that {most} toilets are designed with angled channels from the upper reservoir down into the bowl, which increases directional flow pressure, but the jetting that occurs with normal flush only kick-starts and charges the naturally occuring vortex - or atleast should, if the designer prefers efficiency of application. Done for the purpose of getting the clumps of waste and paper down the drain with ample pressure - so to prevent clogging.

For your own test, take the small waste container in your bathroom, empty it, fill it with water from the tub spicket, and pour it into the toilet bowl quickly. You will see the toilet drain in a vortex, and this will occur without the assistance of "jetting" mechanism from a typical flush.

Crazy stuff that's definitely not worth a subscription to him or that other guy:

1. Waiting for 24 hours to damp all the motion from filling: Wouldn't 5 minutes do?

3. You won't see this in a bathtub or toilet because there are other sources of angular motion that totally wipe out this effect: Oh really, what pray tell, are they?

At the beginning of the video he pulls the plug from 2 sinks. One swirls one way. The other swirls the other way. He doesn't explain this. Is it those other sources of angular motion he mentions but doesn't name? Is it quantum entanglement between the sinks? Or is it really just the initial conditions (the random motion of the water molecules) that set things off in a particular direction. And there are only 2 choices, it seems.

But does water ever run straight down a drain hole? Even at the equator where this Coriolis Effect should be zero? Truth is, you can get water swirling in either direction with a little "swirl" of your own at the beginning. This is how we do science. Theories backed up by simple experiments, and explanations about the differences involved (like how the Coriolis effect is actually not visible in toilets because it's just too weak compared to other factors involved).


Anf of course, that video syncing was genius (although it's a pain in the ass to get the syncing right xD).

A practical, tangible, repeatable, scalable controlled scientific experiment making no assumption about the shape of the earth, using only the natural physical properties of water, showing the earth spins, and is not flat

Have a look at this controlled experiment to detect the Coriolis effect caused by the spin of the earth.

https://youtu.be/mXaad0rsV38

The video is effectively a modern recreation of experiments performed by an MIT professor in mechanical engineering who also studied fluid mechanics, Ascher H Shapiro, in the 1960s.

https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=https://www.technologyreview.com/s/429479/verifying-a-vortex/amp/&ved=2ahUKEwjv4P79gqDeAhXDsY8KHRPuChoQFjAAegQIABAB&usg=AOvVaw3fSztFe-CQLeJP6G8NJGrA&ampcf=1

The Coriolis effect experimental results of prof Shapiro's work were published in the scientific magazine "Nature" in 1962. The experiment has been performed many time all over the world, including in the northern and southern hemispheres.

Cited scientific reference in "Nature": Bath-Tub Vortex, 15 Dec 1962, Vol 196, pp 1080-1081

An actual demonstration of the Coriolis effect in action performed by professor Shapiro can be seen 19-23 mins into the video below.

https://youtu.be/_KMw2bbRfI8

Professor Shapiro's 1962 experiment was repeated by Dr Trefethen of the university of Sydney in 1965.

https://www.australiangeographic.com.au/blogs/dr-karl-need-to-know/2016/06/which-way-does-water-go-down-a-drain/

Cited scientific reference in "Nature": Bath-Tub Vortex in the Southern Hemisphere, Sept 1965, Vol 207, pp 1084-1085

What the first video shows is the water draining away clockwise in the southern hemisphere but counter clockwise in the northern hemisphere. On a spinning flat earth, the water would have drained in the same direction in both hemispheres.

If we now consider lunar eclipses as Aristotle did, we find that the earth always casts a circular shape shadow on the moon.

The only spinning object that casts a circular shadow every time is a sphere. So, the earth is a spinning sphere.

Note : The controlled experiment in the first video can be carried out by anyone with patience and for a few hundred dollars and a quiet space to conduct the experiment. If you have a friend in another hemisphere, he or she can perform the experiment as well, and so the full conclusion of the research can be reached. I.e. the earth is spinning and not flat.

Nature is a British multidisciplinary scientific journal, first published on 4 November 1869. It is one of the most recognizable scientific journals in the world, and was ranked the world's most cited scientific journal by the Science Edition of the 2010 Journal Citation Reports and is ascribed an impact factor of 40.137, making it one of the world's top academic journals. It is one of the few remaining academic journals that publishes original research across a wide range of scientific fields.

Others have stated that their volume of water is too small to be affected by the Coriolis effect. (Cool - affected by an effect). I cannot comment on that but I will say they have proved very little, if anything. If it is true the Coriolis would not apply to their small pools, then each person had a 50/50 chance the water would spin the "right" way and a 25% chance they would both get the predicted result and "prove" that it it does apply to that volume. Sorry but samples of one do not prove anything. If they repeated it a few more times, then it would start to get compelling and might be worthy of a submitting a paper somewhere. The obvious next steps would be to see how small the pool can be and still work. Anyone need a thesis or dissertation topic? No charge. Just give me a shout out. That said, I am glad they did it and thank them for publishing it.

I watched both videos and I was surprised to see no mention of the reason the Coriolis effect is so difficult to observe: it's proportional to the length of the flow, becoming significant for flows of length 10-100 km or more.  I mean the huge scale of the pool wrt the north/south pole kind of gives a clue, but why not explicitly state it ?  That said, I was surprised you could see it in a  ~1m kiddie pool by removing all other horizontal forces (i.e., waiting for it to be completely still).

The scene with the mixed results.... The common sink side by side. The drain for both sinks is no doubt going into one pipe under the sink. Both sinks also share a common vent. The mixed result is the result of the common drain and vent. The water draining from one sink will interfere with the draining of the other sink. If the drain and vents were not common, this would not happen. Attach the left and right drain to separate pipes and separate vents...... you will find that the each sink would drain the water in the same direction every time.

Hey guys, just a quick fyi, yes, coriolis is a real effect, but alas, no one could ever prove that the earth rotates. According to Mach's Principle, the SAME effect would be experienced on a stationary earth in a revolving starfield. Imagine the starfield as a spinning tire, whose center a gravity is empty space. You can put whatever you want in that space and the tire won't touch it. This is Mach's Principle, and is it ever more valid since: 1. No test ever conducted to prove the earth rotates, or moves at all for that matter, has succeeded, and 2.  Mach's Principle requires the earth to occupy a unique position in the cosmos, and ALL quanitifable and measurable observations ever conducted have led to just that. Crazy, huh? Crazy awesome.

At 4:08 he states, "So really you're not gonna see it in a bathtub and you're not gonna see it in a sink or in a toilet because there are other sources of angular momentum that totally wash out this effect." What are those sources? It appears to me that there are multiple variables to be considered before one can definitively "prove" the desired conclusion. Additionally, only one experiment was done. Can we draw a definitive conclusion based on one experiment? Could the direction of the air current above the pool, since it was outside, have affected the direction in which the water drained? Were both platforms identical and completely level? I would be more inclined to consider his conclusions if he and his partner had repeated their experiments multiple times under various conditions and in various locations in the respective hemispheres to prove their hypotheses. Isn't that what the scientific method is all about?

Cute. But WRONG. And here's why:

1. If the theory is correct, the experiment can be replicated with a different set-up. If heavy molecules like water is affected by a spinning ground, a little stream of water going down a wide, slanted plate would produce a NON-straight path as it goes reaching a lower level! But of course it would only go down in a straight path down.

2. A more probable explanation is that the drain hole is not perfectly centered. Also, if a perfectly centered hole should be produced, the water would still go around the hole to overcome it's adhesion with its container. Likewise, pulling a pipe fitted into another pipe is easier if you do so while spinning it. Also, in reverse, an accelerated, light-weight vehicle can "climb" up a nearly vertical wall as it races on perpendicular to the wall, as demonstrated by the "wall of death".

Explanation no.2 also explains the mechanism of the Tesla Turbine, which takes advantage of the nature of flowing liquid.

3. Because the mechanism proposed by the gentlemen in this video would invite an infinite number of contradictions in the real world. One example: If a few feet of length would have induced such difference in the momentum of a heavy liquid, why would a balloon, for a greater length if you'd like, suspended up in a closed room, would not exhibit the same effect? Answer: Because the ground is not moving and is stationary, relative to any other point on the ground in any distance.

HOW TO SYNC BOTH VIDEOS:
Step 1: Open both videos in two separate windows
Step 2: Play both videos, one at a time, and pause both when you see the number 5 countdown start
Step 3: Now that both videos are in pause, split them equally across your PC screen (or one if each monitor if you have dual monitors setup)
Step 4: Repeatedly press ALT+F4 until both videos start playing

What if you are exactly in the Equator

Vortex rotation effect is a result of the centrifugal rotation of magnetic polarity. This effect is also reminiscent of the right-hand/left-hand rules. It's an easy way to test what "pole" is the dominant in your area, and will also tell you how well things can grow there. North pole causes clockwise(looking down on) counter-spatial programming in seeds and eggs, which is unhealthy and usually causes death. The same effect is the cause for wind and stormcloud rotation as well as planetary rotation etc.

This is a fundamental law of nature and is absolutely necessary and unavoidable in logical deconstruction of field physics.

This is fine EXCEPT for the fact that I don't believe a five foot kiddie pool is a large enough body of water to be effected by the "Coriolis Effect". Yes, the Coriolis Effect determines which way large systems/bodies of water rotate but I don't believe it will have a discernible effect on a five foot kiddie pool for the same reason it won't have an effect on a bathtub, sink or toilet. It's FAR to small of a body of water to be effected. ALSO, and this is probably more important, there isn't TIME for that small of a body of water to be effected by the Coriolis Effect. Large planetary systems/bodies of water ARE effected by the Coriolis Effect, small ones are not. Regarding the kiddie pool it could have been the way/angle the drain was installed or how the hole was poked (if there wasn't a drain already installed) it could have been any number of factors JUST like there were factors for how the sink drained one way sometimes and the other way other times.

I'm actually sort of shocked he posted this video. I'm having a really hard time believing that he thinks this actually works on a kiddie pool. I really am. I kept waiting at the end for the "GOTCHA" where he explains that NO it doesn't work on small bodies of water, EVEN A FIVE FOOT KIDDIE POOL. Much like the hucksters that trick tourists at the equator (shown in some of the video excepts he showed from the "Long Way Down" video with Ewan McGregor and Charlie Boorman that he showed here) by showing them which way water drains out of a BUCKET on one side of the equator and then has them step over the equator by only a few feet and supposedly it drains the other way.) Sorry, I just don't believe it works on a small kiddie pool.

"You can see what a tiny little effect it is" says the guy in the vid. That's always been my approach to the hemisphere toilet swirl question, which leaves me with what I regard as a more interesting one: why does water swirl at all when going down a hole? My answer is firstly that it doesn't when the hole is wide enough, it just cascades straight down. Narrow it up and interference or back up effects set it. One of these could be visualised as water separating into streams pushing each other aside as they crowd in and fall.  Which aside must be chancy. Imagine two pool balls colliding head on, which direction does yours then go in - right or left? A dozen factors must affect this, and Coriolis is doubtless one of them. My admiration though for the  way it was isolated and explained.

There's something strange in this experience. The spatial dimension that some motion must have to Coriolis effect have it's importance is the Rossby Deformation Radius. To this problem, even if you're in the southern Australia (-40º os latitude), with 1 meter of pool height, you must have ~28 Km of spatial scale to observe the Coriolis Effect. Considering that you want to observe in a 2 meters diameter pool, you must generate a 10^-5 ms^-1 motion to get 10^-1 (1 order less than one) dimensionless Rossby number and Coriolis effect get it's importance. Sorry if I'm writing some wrong thing, I just get the doubt and want to know what was considered to choose the dimensions of the experience to explain the effect.

Ten or fifteen years ago I saw some article about Japanese scientist who made experiment about water crystals (ice crystals), when he concluded that if you swirling water in clockwise direction, freezing water will form a regular hexagonal  crystals shape. Conversely when water is swirled in opposite direction, its crystals will have an irregular shape. 

At the time when I saw this, I realized how I have the instinct to mix fluids always in a clockwise direction.From then to now I wonder if that instinct is connected with the fact that I'm right-handed, or is it something that has to do with the globe (magnetism or gravity). Also, how to explain why is clockwise direction right direction, and opposite direction is wrong?
Starting today I wonder as well: Do these laws apply equally to the southern hemisphere?
And how to explain this law?

Derek, I actually think you blew this one. I used to believe the toilet theory until I started looking into it. The shape of the bowl will determine which way the water swirls. Some other science site did this experiment by filling a huge vat and trying their darndest to control every aspect from making a perfectly centered hole with no burrs and letting the water sit for three days in a room to acclimate to the temperature and to become still. They even made sure the air in the room was still and the vat was a perfect circle with a smooth surface. Even then the water swirled in a different direction when done several times.
Even tornadoes spin in opposite directions depending on the storm over the same area.
I could be wrong, but from what I have found is the coriolis effect doesn't truly come into play until it is something on a very large scale like hurricanes/typhons.

Has anybody else found this to be the case???

Although the experiment was a success, this can not admitted as proof, since it was 3 experiments (not 6 since each couple is 1 experiment). You will have to replicate it a bunch of time before it can be considered a proof. Plus, one theory says that this will only affect a large body of water, I would be more interested in knowing at what point the effect stops. Think of it this way: a bucket of water is so small that the "farther water" will be close to the "closer water" that the effect should be nullified.

Formula at hand, apparent Coriolis acceleration is 2*w*V*sin(lat). Considering a pool, V~10^-2m/s, while w=2pi/86400 1/s, so Ac=1.45*10^-6 sin(lat), consequently Ac(35 ̊) = 8.34 *10^-7 m/s^2
After 60s the Ac would "cause" a lateral speed of 10^-5 m/s, that means a displacement of .5*Ac*t^2 = 1.5*10^-3 m. This why you need a really still water to see the Coriolis effect in a poll.
At few meters from the equator, the effect is so small that the deviation is less than the dimension of a water molecule.

Have you tried different temperatures? I discovered that if the water is warmer then the environment, it will tend to rotate the same direction as the hemisphere it is on (like cyclone). If it is cooler, then it will rotate the opposite direction (like cool draining water). The direction of rotation is actually the charge/discharge of the medium relative to the charge/discharge of the planetary surface. Charge may be of electric, thermal or other kind (like exposure to the sunlight)
As for the sink drains, you will notice that they tend to rotate in the opposite direction relative to each other, because the rotation describes opposite charge coming together downwards

I have a few issues with your experimental procedure. Mathematically, your pool is not large enough in diameter to exhibit any noticeable effect from the coriolis effect. Second, if your drain is even SLIGHTLY off kilter or off centre (the off centre drains in your kitchen sink explain why they rotate in opposing directions), that will influence the spin of the water far more than the rotation of the earth. Any imperfections in the surface of the drain would affect it as well. It's an interesting demonstration, but I think the random imperfections in the sides of the pool and the surfaces of the drain would influence the direction the water goes more than the rotation of the earth.

Suggestion: Set up five pools in identical manners, cover them with fine mesh to prevent air currents or foreign material from affecting the pool, then drain them all simultaneously. additionally, a neutrally buoyant particulate in the water might be a better way of demonstrating the currents, as dripping dye into the water will introduce currents as well. (I noticed in the video, that you introduced the dye in the same direction as you wanted the water to spin).

I liked this video, but I think to be conclusive you need to perform this experiment in a completely sealed quiescent chamber, so that very local and tiny air flow variations can't affect the result. Despite what our senses tell us, the air outside is in constant motion, and it incredibly turbulent, so removing its effects are essential here. The Coriolis force is obviously going to be a factor in hurricanes as their sizes are so large that there are measurable differences in the relative velocities from north to south. In a kiddy pool... Not so much. The Earth is something like 8-9 orders of magnitude larger. Plus, the way you added the dye was also something that could have imparted angular momentum. AND, you need to use the exact same tub in both the northern and the southern hemispheres. Any slight variation in shape could impart resitance to flow in one direction over another, and preferential rotation will be the result. I think it's too early to judge here. More experiments are needed with sealed chambers, automated dye adding devices, and the same tub.

@Veritasium: Hi Derek, I wanted to start off by saying that I love your channel and videos and I think they're both interesting and informative. I have two questions that are probably pretty stupid. First, when you introduce the die to the water in the kiddie pool does that not add turbulence to the water that could potentially affect which direction the water would swirl? Particularly since the effect is so small, could some small disturbance not overpower the effect and cause the water to swirl in one particular way or another? Secondly I read that the Coriolis effect does not apply to small bodies of water such as sinks and toilet bowls. However it does effect is supposed to apply to large bodies of water which is why hurricanes/typhoons rotate in different directions depending on which hemisphere they are in. But if the effect is so small and so easily overpowered could disturbances in the water not affect which direction the water would swirl?

Cool video(s), although I'm not totally convinced you're actually detecting the Coriolis effect with such a small experiment.
According to my calculations (which admittedly could be faulty), at 33 degrees latitude and a 1.5 m circular pool, the Coriolis velocity difference between the center of the pool and the northernmost /southernmost point in the pool is:
(2*pi*earthradius)*[cos(33 degrees) - cos(33 degrees+(pool radius) radians / earthradius))] / day = 0.03 mm/s.
By the time the water on the edge of the pool makes it to within 1mm of the center of the drain, it would still take over 200 seconds for it to make one full revolution around the drain.
The effect I saw in the video seemed to be larger than this, although maybe my eyes are playing tricks on me.
I'd be more convinced if each experiment was done multiple times.

To be accurate, though, I would think one kiddy pool experiment isn't enough.  I would think you should do 100 draining experiments, or possibly more.  If your results are consistently counterclockwise (outside of some small margin of error) then I would believe in a Coriolis effect on a small level (as opposed to the global level, as in storms and sea currents).
Of course, I know, this is would be incredibly expensive and time consuming, unless you captured the water and pumped it back.

I'm a little skeptical of these results. The Coriolis effect is almost completely undetectable on something the size of a kitty pool. You'd usually need very sophisticated equipment to detect the Coriolis effect across just a few feet.

The tiniest changes in the contours of the kitty pool or even the construction of the drain should have a far greater impact than the Coriolis effect. There's a 25% chance that you would confirm the Coriolis effect even if it had no effect. You said that you repeated the experiment 3 times each, but that was with the same kitty pool. The same kitty pool should generally drain the same way every time.

This would be impractical and unnecessarily difficult, but the true test would be to take many kitty pools and try this experiment several times with each of them. It seems like you could have easily gotten 4 or 5 of these pools and tried the experiment a few times on each of them. That would have brought your chance of a false confirmation down to well below 1%.

I did the the calculation and the difference in velocity between the north side of the pool and the south side at Sydney's latitude is  21.9 cm/h. not a lot.
like so Derek can see! calculation if your wondering is:




 

@ Sydney       cos(33.8650)*1670*10^3  =1386689.238 m/h

@ Sydney + 1.5 meters south    cos(33.8650+(1.5/111.2*10^3))*1670*10^3 = 1386689.019 m/h

1386689.238 - 1386689.019 = 0.219 m/h


33.8650 is latitude of Sydney

1.5 is the pool size (Destin's pool)

111.2 is the length of a degree of latitude on the earths surface in kilometers

1670 is the earth rotation speed in kilometers an hour

*10^3 is to convert kilometers in to meters

equation for speed at certain latitudes is

cos(latitude)*1670

and MAKE SURE YOUR CALCULATOR IS IN DEGREES!

I deal with this sort of motion every time I do a synoptic forecast or analysis. Pressure systems are created due to density differences in the atmosphere caused primarily by uneven heating of the earth's surface. Denser cooler air rushes equatorward from the poles and warm air rushes poleward from the equator. The cyclonic rotation of the earth creates an apparent force called Coriolis force which causes high pressure centers in air masses to rotate clockwise in the Northern Hemisphere and counterclockwise in the Southern Hemisphere. The reverse is true for low pressure centers such as in the pool. The closer to the poles the more the rotation of the earth causes Coriolis effects. Upward and downward vertical motions also are involved in which a veering or backing effect takes place to conserve angular momentum. The Hadley cell's circulation near the equator is there due to band of low pressure and cyclones which develops due to heating causing warm air to rise. Coriolis force deflects the air to the right as it rises till it sinks back down in the subtropical region diverging anticyclonically on the surface. The interaction between the surface cyclonic flow near the equator and anticyclonic flow in the subtropical region creates the easterly trade winds at the base of the Hadley cell. The moisture along the equatorial regions is water vapor  due to heating of the surface which rises till it condenses. Quite often in June through November with enough warm water and moisture in a cyclonic flow you get typhoons and hurricanes. The moisture and heat creates a buoyant flow. The winds get faster in the cyclone as a result creating more centripetal force and an eye. Land and cool currents or wind shear etc can disrupt the flow and it will fall apart. Fun stuff.

To synchronize the 2 videos, open 2 browsers and set them up side by side then set up one of the videos in each browser. Play Derek's video until he finishes his countdown then pause it (so 5,4,3,2,1,pause). Then play Destin's video, when he finishes his countdown hit play on Derek's video (so 5,4,3,2,1,play). The videos should be nicely synchronized.

I find the explanation when the bullet crosses latitude lines easy to understand, and I can even understand how altitude adjustment depends on true azimuth.

The tricky one is when the bullet moves straight E/W. I think I can explain it on the basis of a frame of reference (planar to polar) difference, as the bullet flies in tangent to the planet. But, I'd love to hear a more concise, intuitive explanation....

Hang on, do the math guys. Coriolis force is negligible for a 2m diameter kiddie pool. It's only observable on very large areas like storm systems. Your apparatus has more bias attributable to wrinkles in the pool, angle alignment of the drain, etc that are orders of magnitude greater impact than Coriolis at that scale. Large number of trials with the same apparatus won't average out that bias because it's built into the system of measurement. How about getting a rigid body basin and taking the same apparatus to several latitudes and doing trials?

This has been done before - I saw the experiment done in the '80s. The Coriolis is so small that small perturbations in the construction of the drain could easily be amplified and become much larger than the Coriolis. The proper way to conduct this test is to repeat it many times and take the exact environment "down under" and do the same thing. As I recall, the earlier experiment was repeated 100 times, and the numbers were 49 to 51 - completely inconclusive.

Derek, do you realize that the graphic pool in the southern hemisphere you made was HUGE? The dimensions of the actual pool in the experiment render it as a mere dot compared to Earth's radius, ergo it can be approximated as dimensionless and the Earth's rotation would not play a significant role to the draining rotation of the pool. Also, the graphic model you made was an extreme case and did not explain the motion that Australia is doing. And lastly, you did ONE experiment. You should do many pools at the same time in multiple locations and have counter data from the northern hemisphere. If ALL the pools in the northern hemisphere rotate counterclockwise and respectively those southern rotate clockwise, then you can conclude that this phenomenon is true.

Nope, its not true, unless you did a scientifically controlled study of a bunch of pools, a bunch of times, this is not proof.

Besides, the water should swirl in the other way, the water further away from the pole would be moving contrary to the rotation, and the water close to the pool, has less momentum so it can be influenced by the water movement on the other side of the pool easier.

Youre right about the momentum being stronger away from the pole, but the pool is moving faster than the water, the water should be flowing against the movement.

It is either random, or it is backwards from this video, because i bet you the drain texture, even slight rifling, can polarize the water flow right at the drain, and that would influence water flow throughout the body of still water.

Because thats the thing, either the water is still, or its not, if its not still then either you can just detect rotation of the earth with that, or its not the rotation of the earth at all, and if its still, completely free falling in the container, then even the drain can polarize water flow

>Open two windows open each video in different windows

>Veritasium video should be on the right side

I have a problem with this. I tryed it, and actually reversed the flow intentionally, and at least where i live if i have a fairly small hole and a fairly symmetric container, the water reverse it self back to the original motion. And i done it multiple times, talking about maybe 50 or so. The result is always the same.

I never been to Australia, but i been to South Africa, and there it just didn work.

Note, i live less then half the distance from the pole relative to the equator. Sidney on the other hand is a lot closer to the equator than the pole.

So Sidney is not a optimal place to try this out. Well, sure, if you want to prove that it can be done in places where the effect is low, then this shows it perfectly.

But its not very scientific. To make it really scientific should stop the rotation as good as possible and try multiple times with varying times. Also i thing try with less water in. Rather 5 cm or so than 30. Also try two different latitudes and see how much diffrentse there in in the Coriolis effect speeding it up.
